head.title: Containers Easy On the Ozone Layer

hedline.hl1: Containers Easy On the Ozone Layer

block.p: "Moving Fast to Protect Ozone Layer" (Business Day, May 15) accurately points out the positive steps that industry is taking to reduce the use of chlorofluorocarbons. However, the statement that a primary use of CFC's is "making foam for . . food packaging" is incorrect.

"Moving Fast to Protect Ozone Layer" (Business Day, May 15) accurately points out the positive steps that industry is taking to reduce the use of chlorofluorocarbons. However, the statement that a primary use of CFC's is "making foam for . . food packaging" is incorrect.

In 1989, the foam food-service products industry became the first to announce a phase-out of fully halogenated CFC's, the chemicals considered most damaging to the stratospheric ozone layer. This program, developed in cooperation with major environmental groups, was applauded by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and the United Nations Environment Program. In fact, the Foodservice & Packaging Institute was given the E. P. A.'s Stratospheric Ozone Protection Award.

At its peak, CFC usage by the foam food-service products industry represented less than 3 percent of CFC's used in the United States annually -- only about 30 percent of foam food-service containers were ever made with CFC's. Now 100 percent are made without.

The foam food-service products industry spent millions to convert away from fully halogenated CFC's. Misinformation regarding these efforts does severe damage to companies that are trying to be environmentally responsible. JOSEPH W. BOW President Foodservice & Packaging Institute Washington, May 15, 1991
